factoid: The narrator is alone in charge of three hospitals.
The narrator has more than four hundred patients.
Charitable Prussian ladies send two pounds of coffee and some lint each month to the narrator's hospitals.
Without the coffee and lint the narrator's hospitals would be lost.
The narrator says there are four hundred patients and that the Prussian ladies always send fresh coffee.
Rostóv says Major Denísov was wounded at Molliten.
The doctor thinks Major Denísov is dead.
The doctor asks whether Major Denísov is tall and has reddish hair.
Rostóv describes Major Denísov's appearance.
The doctor says "There was one like that" and "That one is dead, I fancy."
The doctor will look up the list of soldiers.
The assistant says Makár Alexéevich has the list.
The assistant says if you step into the officers' wards you will see for yourself.
The doctor says you better not go or you may have to stay here yourself.
The doctor shouts "Only don't blame me!".
Rostóv and the assistant enter a dark corridor.
The corridor has a strong smell that makes Rostóv hold his nose and pause.
A door opens to the right in the corridor.
An emaciated sallow man on crutches, barefoot, in underclothing, limps out of the door and leans against the doorpost.
The man looks with glittering envious eyes at those passing.
Rostóv sees that sick and wounded lie on the floor on straw and overcoats.
The assistant does not want Rostóv to go into the soldiers' ward.
Rostóv enters the soldiers' ward.
The air in the soldiers' ward is stronger and more pungent than in the corridor.
The long room is brightly lit by the sun through large windows.
Sick and wounded lie in two rows with their heads to the walls, leaving a passage in the middle.
Most of the sick and wounded are unconscious and ignore newcomers.
The conscious sick and wounded raise themselves or lift their thin yellow faces.
The conscious sick and wounded look intently at Rostóv with expressions of hope, relief, reproach, and envy.
Rostóv goes to the middle of the room and looks through open doors into adjoining rooms.
Rostóv sees the same arrangement of sick and wounded in the adjoining rooms.
A sick man, probably a Cossack by hair cut, lies on the bare floor across the middle of the passage.
The man lies on his back with his arms and legs outstretched.
The man's face is purple.
The man's eyes are rolled back, showing only the whites.
The man's bare legs and arms are red and veins stand out like cords.
The man knocks the back of his head against the floor.
The man hoarsely utters the words "drink, drink, a drink!".
Rostóv looks for someone to put the man back in his place and bring him water.
Rostóv asks the assistant "Who looks after the sick here?".
A commissariat soldier, hospital orderly, comes in from the next room, marches stiffly, and draws up in front of Rostóv.
The soldier shouts "Good day, your honor!".
The soldier rolls eyes at Rostóv and mistakenly thinks Rostóv is a hospital authority.
Rostóv says "Get him to his place and give him some water" pointing to the Cossack.
The soldier replies "Yes, your honor" complacently, rolls eyes more, draws himself up straighter, but does not move.
